title: Is the sentence “there are full of ‘something’” correct? - Quora

response.answer_text: We all agree that it is not correct. I will explain what I think you are trying to say and why it doesn’t work: That place is full of something. For example: That closet is full of clothes. That city is full of people. Then you’re thinking that we can use the word “there” to mean “that place.” And we can: Put your clothes in the closet-> Put your clothes there. I want to go to that city-> I want to go there. But! When “there” means “that place” it can only be an adverb. It cannot be the subject of the sentence. However! There’s a different word “there” that does NOT mean “in that place.” It is only used as the fill-in subject of a sentence; there is or there are. It means “exists.” A pond exists in that place-> There is a pond there. The first “there” means exists. The second “there” means “in that place.” Some people are in that place-> There are some people there. The first “there” means exists. The second “there” means “in that place.” ~~~ So the problem with your sentence is that you are using the “in-that-place” meaning in a spot where you can only use the “exists” meaning. You are mixing them both together. And that doesn’t work.

No, it is not correct, and I’m not even clear about what it is trying to say. Some context would be helpful here. If you had noticed that some bags or boxes were unexpectedly heavy, but did not know what was in them, you could say: ‘They are full of something!’ or ‘They seem to be full of something!’ or ‘They must be full of something!’ But never ‘there must be full of something’. Also, there is no reason I can think of why you would normally want to put single inverted commas just around the word ‘something’. Perhaps if you were referring not to an unknown thing but to something in particular, and you knew what that thing was and your audience also knew what it was, but you didn’t want to say what it was out loud because the thing in question was a big secret between the two of you, then it might make some kind of sense to add the inverted commas!

Is the sentence “there are full of ‘something’” correct? Is the sentence “There are full of ‘something’” correct? No it isn’t. The wrong version of “there are” has been used. Of the three similar sounding words: there, their and they’re; “they’re”, meaning, “They are”, should have been used. In Britain, “they’re full of something”, is sometime used as a semi-sarcastic, witty retort to someone who has just said something that included the phrase “full of”. I.e.: Person 1: They are full of the joys of Spring. Person 2: They’re full of something! (meaning Winter is over and hormones have begun to rise).

There are full of something is not a sentence because it has no subject. If you substitute “They are” for “There” you have the beginning of a sentence, but it is not a complete idea. “They are full of happy thoughts after the birthday party” is a complete sentence because it conveys a complete idea.

It’s not incorrect to say that there is a fullness of something or a plenitude of something. However, it’s incorrect to say that there are full of something. At least in English. (In everyday Hebrew, it’s often heard.)
